On Differential Privacy for Federated Learning in Wireless Systems with Multiple Base Stations

Abstract

In this work, we consider a federated learning model in a wireless system with multiple base stations and inter-cell interference. We apply a differential private scheme to transmit information from users to their corresponding base station during the learning phase. We show the convergence behavior of the learning process by deriving an upper bound on its optimality gap. Furthermore, we define an optimization problem to reduce this upper bound and the total privacy leakage. To find the locally optimal solutions of this problem, we first propose an algorithm that schedules the resource blocks and users. We then extend this scheme to reduce the total privacy leakage by optimizing the differential privacy artificial noise. We apply the solutions of these two procedures as parameters of a federated learning system. In this setting, we assume that each user is equipped with a classifier. Moreover, the communication cells are assumed to have mostly fewer resource blocks than numbers of users. The simulation results show that our proposed scheduler improves the average accuracy of the predictions compared with a random scheduler. Furthermore, its extended version with noise optimizer significantly reduces the amount of privacy leakage.

Index Terms:
Differential privacy, federated learning, neural networks, wireless channel, multiple base stations.

I Introduction

Machine Learning (ML) systems are expected to play an important role in future mobile communication standardsÂ [1]. With increasing applications of ML schemes in wireless systems, new technologies are emerging to enhance the performance of such systems. On the other hand the wireless technology itself can also be deployed to enhance the ML proceduresÂ [2]. Among possible candidates, Federated Learning (FL) has been shown to have considerable promiseÂ [3, 4, 5] and has the potential to benefit from wireless communication.

FL solves several issues of centralized ML systems by distributing the learning task among several edge devices. One advantage of using an FL system, which makes it a good fit in a wireless setting, is that edge devices do not need to transmit their local datasets to the server. This reduces the amount of wireless resources that is required for accomplishing the given ML task. Apart from this, the privacy of each edge device is not completely compromised since the server does not have a direct access to the dataÂ [6].

FL schemes operating over wireless networks have been extensively researched in recent years; see for exampleÂ [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. InÂ [8], the authors studied the effects of wireless parameters on the FL process. They derived an upper bound on the optimality gap of the convergence terms and proposed an optimization problem to minimize the upper bound by considering wireless parameters like resource allocation, user scheduling, and packet error rate. Some other works that studied the communication aspects of FL areÂ [14, 15, 16]. Moreover, FL with several layers of aggregation or with hierarchy has been studied inÂ [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22].

Although the training data of each device in FL is not transmitted to the server, yet a function of the local model (query) is still sent to the server. It has been shown that this local model might leak some information about the training dataÂ [23]. To mitigate this drawback, FL has been extensively studied together with a privacy preserving scheme called Differential Privacy (DP)Â [24].

DP-based schemes follow the principle of not being adversely affected much by having oneâ€™s data used in any analysisÂ [25]. This powerful notion is well established and is applied in industry. To realize a DP-based FL system, each edge device adds some artificial noise to its transmitting information. This noise provides a certain amount of privacy depending on the noise power and sensitivity of the query function.

DP based FL and its convergence behavior have been extensively studied; see for exampleÂ [26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32]. In this regard, the work inÂ [26] addresses the privacy implementation challenges through a combination of zero-concentrated differential privacy, local gradient perturbation and secure aggregation.[30] considers the resource allocation and user scheduling to minimize the FL training delay under the constraint of performance and DP requirements. Finally,Â [32] presents a closed-form global loss and privacy leakage of a DP-based FL system and then minimizes the loss and privacy leakage.

However, none of these works consider a joint learning and resource allocation scheme for DP-based FL that considers the effects of inter-cell interference as well. In this paper, we adapt the framework inÂ [8] and consider a wireless FL system in a multiple base station scenario. Additionally, we consider DP noise added to the gradientsÂ [26] and combine this approach with resource scheduling.

The goal of the FL system here is to train a global model for a given predictor. We introduce an iterative DP-based FL scheme with two levels of aggregation (AlgorithmÂ 1) and then derive an upper bound on the optimality gap of its convergence terms (TheoremÂ 1).

We then propose an optimization problem whose goal is to improve the convergence of the upper bound on the optimality gap of AlgorithmÂ 1 and simultaneously reduce the total privacy leakage. In this regard, the optimization problem is with respect to certain variables like user and resource scheduling, uplink transmit powers, and the amount of DP noise that is applied by each user to its transmitting information.

Since the proposed optimization problem is a non-linear multi-variable mixed integer programming, we divide it into two simpler schemes.

First, we present a suboptimal approach to minimize the objective function only with respect to resource scheduling variables in a sequential manner, i.e., cell by cell. This reduces the original problem to a linear integer programming task and substantially simplifies the implementation. We call this scheme also the optimal scheduler (OptSched). Since this approach performs sequentially from one cell to another one, the amounts of optimal transmit power should be adjusted carefully due to the effects of inter-cell interference. To tackle this problem, we introduce a procedure to determine the usersâ€™ optimal transmit powers by solving a simple optimization problem.

Next, we enhance the OptSched scheme by further minimizing the objective function of the proposed optimization problem with respect to the DP noise. This leads us to a convex optimization problem with respect to the DP noise standard deviations. We call this extended scheme the optimal scheduler with DP optimizer (OptSched+DP).

We present all the numerical optimizations and benchmarking results. In this regard, we apply Python optimization packages like CVXPY, CVXOPT, GLPK, and ECOSÂ [33, 34, 35, 36, 37]. The numerical results show that our proposed schemes (OptSched and OptSched+DP) reduce the objective function of the optimization task substantially compared with the case in which we randomly allocate the resources and apply the DP noise.

Next, we apply these (sub-)optimal parameters to our iterative learning scheme (AlgorithmÂ 1). In this regard, each user is equipped with a fully connected multi-layer neural network as a classifier. Furthermore, we assume that communication cells have mainly more users than available resource blocks. This is a legitimate assumption due to the bandwidth limitation. We then perform simulations to measure the accuracy, loss, and the amount of the privacy leakage in such a system for the proposed algorithms. To realize the simulations, we apply the TensorFlow, NumPy, and Matplotlib packagesÂ [38, 39, 40].

The simulations show that the OptSched scheme predominantly improves the classification accuracy by scheduling the users who have larger data chunks and better uplink channels. The OptSched+DP scheme, on the other hand, achieves a significant reduction in privacy leakage of individual users by systematically adjusting the DP noise power and moderately sacrificing accuracy.

One difference between AlgorithmÂ 1 and other approaches like e.g. the FL schemes inÂ [26, 8] is that here the aggregation is done in two steps. Additionally, the noise standard deviations Ïƒs,isubscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–\sigma_{s,i} at users are not necessarily identical here and a joint optimal user scheduling and DP noise adjustment is possible.

To characterize the DP noise, we need to make the following assumption which can be achieved in practice by weight clippingÂ [43, 26].

Assumption 1.

The gradients of the local loss functions are always upper bounded:

is the privacy leakage.

Note that the DP noise affects the convergence of the learning process as well. In SectionÂ III, we study the convergence behavior of AlgorithmÂ 1 with respect to the vector parameters ğ’‚ssubscriptğ’‚ğ‘ \bm{a}_{s} and ğˆssubscriptğˆğ‘ \bm{\sigma}_{s}.

III Convergence Analysis

In the following, we define the global loss as a function of local losses. We then derive an upper bound on the optimality gap that appears in each round of AlgorithmÂ 1.

The global loss function is computed over all base stations and is given by

fâ€‹(ğ’˜(t))â‰”1Kâ€‹âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’°sâˆ‘k=1Ks,ilâ€‹(ğ’˜(t),ğ’™s,i(k)),â‰”ğ‘“superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ ğ’®subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’°ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘™superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle f(\bm{w}^{(t)})\coloneqq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\sum_{k=1}^{K_{s,i}}l(\bm{w}^{(t)},\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(k)}), (12)

Hence, by lowering the values of C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}, C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}, and C3subscriptğ¶3C_{3}, the convergence of AlgorithmÂ 1 should be improved. We also observe that the upper bound converges only if C1<1subscriptğ¶11C_{1}<1. In SectionÂ IV, we design an optimal scheduler and a DP optimizer based on these variables and their effect on this upper bound.

IV Learning over Wireless Channels with Inter-cell Interference

In this section, we consider other wireless parameters of the communication system and connect them to the notion of learning. These wireless parameters include resource allocation, transmit power consumption, fading channels, inter-cell interference, and communication rate.

We assume that the users apply an Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) technique in the uplink channel to transmit data to their corresponding base station. In this case, each edge device iâˆˆğ’°sğ‘–subscriptğ’°ğ‘ i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} is assigned a resource block indexed by nâˆˆ[R]ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘…n\in[R] where Rğ‘…R is the total number of available uplink transmission resource blocks in each cell.

Before applying these wireless parameters in the learning process, we first need to introduce another measure based on the DP standard deviations (ğˆs)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptğˆğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}}. In this regard, we define the total privacy leakage as follows:

In this definition, the summands inÂ (19) are computed by multiplying the privacy leakage given byÂ (11) at each user with the scheduling variables as,isubscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–a_{s,i}. Minimizing this measure reduces the individual privacy leakage as well. This improvement is due to the systematic adjustment of the DP noise power at each user. In this case, edge devices who have a larger number of samples Ks,isubscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–K_{s,i} are assigned less DP noise power.

The parameters ğ‘¹ssubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ \bm{R}_{s} and ğˆssubscriptğˆğ‘ \bm{\sigma}_{s} play a critical role in improving the convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 1 (cf. TheoremÂ 1) and reducing the total privacy leakage. Furthermore, the parameter ğ’‘ssubscriptğ’‘ğ‘ \bm{p}_{s} is critical in establishing a reliable communication. By minimizing C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} with respect to these parameters, the upper bound on the optimality gap in TheoremÂ 1 reduces and thus the convergence rate of the FL procedure should improve. To this end, it is sufficient to minimize only the expressions inside the squared term in C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}.

Therefore, we propose an optimization problem over the variables (ğ‘¹s,ğ’‘s,ğˆs)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ subscriptğ’‘ğ‘ subscriptğˆğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{R}_{s},\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} and minimize the values of C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} from TheoremÂ 1 and the total privacy leakage given byÂ (19). The main server can then solve this optimization problem and then broadcast the results to all base stations before AlgorithmÂ 1 starts.

where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is a constant and is used to balance the optimization of the scheduling and the total privacy leakage. Typically, the value of the constant Î³ğ›¾\gamma can be obtained by hyperparameter tuning and simulations.

Minimizing the first term in the objective function inÂ (20) improves the convergence of AlgorithmÂ 1 and is computed by applyingÂ (14) to the summation term in C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} of TheoremÂ 1. Minimizing the second term, on the other hand, reduces the total privacy leakage at all users and is given byÂ (19).

ConstraintÂ (21) guarantees that the DP noise error, which is characterized by the term C3subscriptğ¶3C_{3} of TheoremÂ 1, is less than a given constant Vmaxsubscriptğ‘‰V_{\max}. To derive conditionÂ (21), we first consider the following upper bound on the squared term in C3subscriptğ¶3C_{3}

(Ks,iâ€‹as,iKaâ€‹Ïƒs,i)2â‰¤Ks,iâ€‹as,iKaâ€‹Ïƒs,i2,superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ¾asubscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–2subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ¾asuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–2\displaystyle\Big{(}\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}\Big{)}^{2}\leq\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}^{2}, (27)

which follows byÂ (10) and Ks,iâ€‹as,iâ‰¤Kasubscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ¾aK_{s,i}a_{s,i}\leq K_{\mathrm{a}}. ConstraintÂ (21) then follows by applyingÂ (10) andÂ (14) to this upper bound and setting it to be smaller than Vmaxsubscriptğ‘‰V_{\max}. We can then control the amount of DP noise variance and its error by adjusting the constant Vmaxsubscriptğ‘‰V_{\max}.

ConditionsÂ (23)-(24) provide the resource allocation constraints, whereasÂ (25)-(26) restrict the transmit power to a maximum amount Pmaxsubscriptğ‘ƒmaxP_{\mathrm{max}} and ensure a minimum communication rate Rminsubscriptğ‘…minR_{\mathrm{min}} for each user in each cell, respectively. Finally, constraintÂ (22) guarantees an upper bound on the privacy leakage of the users individually due toÂ (11). In this case, the constant Nminsubscriptğ‘N_{\min} controls the minimum amount of DP noise at each user.

We notice that the variable ğ’‚ssubscriptğ’‚ğ‘ \bm{a}_{s} and ğ‘¹ssubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ \bm{R}_{s}, which are given byÂ (3) andÂ (13), are related due toÂ (14). Therefore, ğ’‚ssubscriptğ’‚ğ‘ \bm{a}_{s} does not appear as a minimization variable.

The optimization problem inÂ (20) is not easy to solve. However, we can subdivide it into simpler problems and search for (sub-)optimal solutions. The main server can then compute and broadcast these (sub-)optimal (ğ‘¹sâˆ—,ğ’‘sâˆ—,ğˆsâˆ—)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğˆğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{R}_{s}^{*},\bm{p}_{s}^{*},\bm{\sigma}_{s}^{*})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} to all base stations where they can be forwarded to the users. These computations and initialization should be done prior to the beginning of AlgorithmÂ 1.

V Algorithm Design

In this section, we propose two suboptimal sequential algorithms to solve the optimization problem inÂ (20). First, for fixed DP noise the objective function inÂ (20) is minimized with respect to usersâ€™ transmit powers and resource block allocation in a cell-by-cell manner. In the second part, with given transmit power and resource block allocation, the optimization problem inÂ (20) becomes convex with respect to the DP noise standard deviations.

After finding the optimal powers fromÂ (35), we can compute the uplink communication rates by usingÂ (18). We then unschedule those users whose rates do not satisfyÂ (26) and set their transmit power to zero.

Based on these solutions, we propose two procedures for user scheduling and DP noise adjustment. AlgorithmÂ 2 presents a random scheduler (RndSched). AlgorithmÂ 3 provides an optimal scheduler (OptSched) based onÂ (30). Both algorithms benefit from the power allocation procedure based onÂ (35) and both apply random DP noise to achieve privacy.

We note that one advantage of the optimal scheduler is that it is linear and therefore efficient from a practical point of view compared withÂ (28). Nevertheless, the drawback of this approach is that it is performed sequentially and cell by cell. As a result, there is no guarantee that this approach always provides us with an optimal solution. However, as we will see in SubsectionÂ VI-A, it delivers very good results compared with the randomized scheduler. In the next subsection, we extend this algorithm to include a DP optimizer.

=Vmaxâ€‹âˆ‘sâˆˆğ’®âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’°sKs,iâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Rrs,i(n).absentsubscriptğ‘‰subscriptğ‘ ğ’®subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’°ğ‘ subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›\displaystyle=V_{\max}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}. (39)

After the value of Îºğœ…\kappa is found fromÂ (V-B), the optimal Ïƒs,iâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–\sigma^{*}_{s,i} can be computed fromÂ (38). We then combine this scheme with the procedure in SubsectionÂ V-A. A summary of this scheme is provided in AlgorithmÂ 4 (OptSched+DP).

VI Simulations and Numerical Solutions

VI-A Optimization Problems

In this subsection, we present the numerical solutions of the algorithms that were presented in SectionÂ V. In this regard, we apply the Python optimization packages CVXPY, CVXOPT, GLPK, and ECOSÂ [33, 34, 35, 36, 37].

Since AlgorithmsÂ 3 andÂ 4 are heuristic, their solutions depend on the initial values of the optimizing variables (ğ‘¹s,ğ’‘s,ğˆs)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ subscriptğ’‘ğ‘ subscriptğˆğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{R}_{s},\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} as well as the wireless channels and the number of training samples at each user. As a result, we repeat the computations for several random initial values, channels and data distributions among the users and then compute the average.

To this end, the variables (ğ‘¹s)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{R}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} are first initialized based on a shuffled Round-robin scheme and (ğ’‘s,ğˆs)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptğ’‘ğ‘ subscriptğˆğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} are set uniformly at random such that 0â‰¤ps,iâ‰¤Pmax0subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒ0\leq p_{s,i}\leq P_{\max} and Nmin/Ks,iâ‰¤Ïƒs,iâ‰¤6â€‹Nmin/Ks,isubscriptğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘ ğ‘–6subscriptğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–N_{\min}/K_{s,i}\leq\sigma_{s,i}\leq 6N_{\min}/K_{s,i} hold. Second, the users are positioned in a square area consisting of seven hexagon cells according to a uniform distribution. The edge devices are then assigned to their nearest base stations according to their random position. Based on their distances to the base stations, their fading channels are then computed by applyingÂ (17).

An example of channel initialization, which is generated by our simulator in Python language, is shown in Fig.Â 3. In this case, the channels between one of the users and base stations are depicted as dashed lines. We notice that the cells 1-6 in this setting can cover users also outside their area while the central cell only covers devices inside the central hexagon. As a result, the effects of boundary and central cells are both taken into account in our simulations.

After the users are assigned to their corresponding base stations, the training data is randomly distributed among all users. Inspired byÂ [48], the number of samples Ks,isubscriptğ¾ğ‘ ğ‘–K_{s,i} are determined by a lognormal distribution.

AlgorithmsÂ 3 andÂ 4 should then provide us with (ğ‘¹sâˆ—,ğ’‘sâˆ—)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¹ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğ’‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{R}^{*}_{s},\bm{p}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} and (ğ’‚sâˆ—)sâˆˆğ’®subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’‚ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ’®(\bm{a}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} which determine (sub-)optimal allocated resource blocks, uplink transmit powers, and the scheduled users.

The system parameters that are used in the computations are listed in TableÂ I. Fig.Â 4 shows the results of all algorithms in the form of an empirical Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of the normalized objective value inÂ (20). The normalization is done by dividing the value of the objective function by the total number of samples (scheduled or unscheduled). The CDF is computed for two values of available number of resource blocks Rğ‘…R and the optimization constant Î³ğ›¾\gamma fromÂ (20) . The results are averaged over 103superscript10310^{3} random channels and initial values. As seen in Fig.Â 4, the OptSched (AlgorithmÂ 3) outperforms the RndSched (AlgorithmÂ 2) in terms of minimizing the objective value inÂ (20). Moreover, the OptSched+DP (AlgorithmÂ 4) further improves the results of the OptSched by reducing the total privacy leakage. Furthermore, the OptSched+DP achieves lower values for Î³=107ğ›¾superscript107\gamma=10^{7} compared with the case in which Î³=106ğ›¾superscript106\gamma=10^{6}. This is because, larger Î³ğ›¾\gamma inÂ (20) gives more weight to the DP noise optimization.

We also notice that by increasing Rğ‘…R from 5 to 8, the normalized objective values of the RndSched get slightly closer to the outcome of the OptSched algorithm. This is due to the fact that by increasing Rğ‘…R and keeping the total number of users constant, chances that all users are successfully scheduled by RndSched become higher. In this case, for large values of Rğ‘…R, the RndSched might eventually achieves the same performance as for OptSched. However, the choice of selecting a large number of resource blocks for a low number of users is not desirable due to the limited amount of available bandwidth.

VI-B Federated Learning Simulations

In this subsection, we apply the random parameters ğ’‚ssubscriptğ’‚ğ‘ \bm{a}_{s} and ğˆssubscriptğˆğ‘ \bm{\sigma}_{s} as well as (sub-)optimal ğ’‚sâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ’‚ğ‘ \bm{a}^{*}_{s} and ğˆsâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğˆğ‘ \bm{\sigma}^{*}_{s} from SubsectionÂ VI-A to an FL system as described in AlgorithmÂ 1. In this case, we assume that the main server and all users each maintain a fully connected neural network in the form of a multi-label classifier. The networks consist of two hidden layers, each with 256 nodes. To implement the simulations, we apply the TensorFlow, NumPy, and Matplotlib packagesÂ [38, 39, 40]. Furthermore, we use the MNIST image datasetÂ [49] to train and test the multi-label classifier.

In this setting, we train the local models over T=200ğ‘‡200T=200 communication rounds between users and the main server. To follow our mathematical model in SectionÂ II, we perform no local iterations and use the batch gradient descent scheme. We do not apply any decay and use a fixed learning rate Î»=0.05ğœ†0.05\lambda=0.05.

Furthermore, to guarantee that AssumptionÂ 1 holds, the gradient of all weights are clipped so that their global norm is smaller than or equal to L=10ğ¿10L=10. This directly affects the amount of privacy leakage as given byÂ (11).

We perform the simulations over 100 channels and initial values and then average the resulting accuracy and loss. Furthermore, we generate the empirical CDF of the privacy leakage of all users. Fig.Â 5 shows the accuracy, loss, and privacy leakage CDF of this learning system for different values of available resource blocks Rğ‘…R and optimization constant Î³ğ›¾\gamma.

As seen in Fig.Â 5, the OptSched outperforms the RndSched algorithm in terms of accuracy and loss for both R=5ğ‘…5R=5 and R=8ğ‘…8R=8. In this case, the OptSched systematically selects the users with large chunks of data that have a better channel and suffer less from the inter-cell interference. The RndSched algorithm, however, fails in this scenario since it applies a random scheduling scheme.

The OptSched+DP, on the other hand, slightly degrades the performance of the optimal scheduler by increasing and optimizing the DP noise. Yet OptSched+DP provides a similar or even better performance compared with RndSched scheme for small values of Rğ‘…R (see FigsÂ 5(a) andÂ 5(c)). The degradation is the price that is paid to improve the privacy. Figs.Â 5(e) andÂ 5(f) show the empirical CDF of the privacy leakage (ÏğœŒ\rho). In this case, the value of ÏğœŒ\rho at each user is computed by usingÂ (11) and the results over all simulation iterations are collected to compute the CDF. The simulations show that the OptSched+DP scheme substantially reduces the amount of privacy leakage at each user. In particular it achieves a maximum privacy leakage of around Ï=0.5ğœŒ0.5\rho=0.5 thanks to the DP optimizer scheme. This is a significant improvement compared with the RndSched scheme with a maximum leakage of around Ï=4ğœŒ4\rho=4.

Adjusting the optimization constant Î³ğ›¾\gamma is also crucial. In this regard, by choosing Î³=107ğ›¾superscript107\gamma=10^{7} the OptSched achieves lower privacy leakage compared with Î³=106ğ›¾superscript106\gamma=10^{6} (see Figs.Â 5(e) andÂ 5(f)). This is because larger Î³ğ›¾\gamma gives less weight to the optimal scheduler inÂ (20) and users with higher DP noise power are preferred in scheduling.

VII Conclusion

In this work, a privacy preserving FL procedure in a multiple base station scenario with inter-cell interference has been considered. An upper bound on the optimality gap of the convergence term of this learning scheme has been derived and an optimization problem to reduce this upper bound has been provided. We have proposed two sequential algorithms to obtain (sub-)optimal solutions for this optimization task; namely an optimal scheduler (OptSched) in AlgorithmÂ 3 and its extended version with DP optimizer (OptSched+DP) in AlgorithmÂ 4. In designing these schemes we avoid non-linearity in the integer programming problems. The outputs of these algorithms are then applied to an FL system.

Simulation results have shown that the OptSched increases the accuracy of the classification FL system and reduces the loss compared with the RndSched when the number of available resource blocks Rğ‘…R is small. In this case, when the total number of users is K=100ğ¾100K=100 and R=5ğ‘…5R=5, the OptSched shows an accuracy improvement of over 6%percent66\%. Simulations have further shown that the OptSched not only improves the accuracy but also can reduce the privacy leakage compared with the RndSched if the parameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma is set properly.

The OptSched+DP, on the other hand, further optimizes the DP noise and substantially reduces the privacy leakage compared with both RndSched and OptSched. In this case, simulations have shown that the OptSched+DP reduces the maximum privacy leakage for both R=5ğ‘…5R=5 and R=8ğ‘…8R=8 by a factor of 8 (from Ï=4ğœŒ4\rho=4 to Ï=0.5ğœŒ0.5\rho=0.5). It is worth mentioning that when Rğ‘…R is small (e.g. R=5ğ‘…5R=5), this improvement is achieved while OptSched+DP shows a similar or even better performance in terms of accuracy and loss compared with RndSched.
